cleaned_text: Hygiene Hygiene is a set of practices performed to preserve [health](/wiki/Health). According to the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO), "Hygiene refers to conditions and practices that help to maintain health and prevent the spread of [diseases](/wiki/Disease)." [[2]](#cite_note-2) Personal hygiene refers to maintaining the body's cleanliness. Hygiene activities can be grouped into the following: home and everyday hygiene, personal hygiene, medical hygiene, sleep hygiene, and [food hygiene](/wiki/Food_safety). Home and every day hygiene includes [hand washing](/wiki/Hand_washing), respiratory hygiene, food hygiene at home, hygiene in the kitchen, hygiene in the bathroom, laundry hygiene, and medical hygiene at home. Many people equate hygiene with "cleanliness", but hygiene is a broad term. It includes such personal habit choices as how frequently to take a shower or bath, wash hands, trim [fingernails](/wiki/Nail_(anatomy)), and wash clothes. It also includes attention to keeping surfaces in the home and workplace clean, including [bathroom](/wiki/Bathroom) facilities. Adherence to regular hygiene practices is often regarded as a socially responsible and respectable behavior, while neglecting proper hygiene can be perceived as unclean or unsanitary, and may be considered socially unacceptable or disrespectful, while also posing a risk to public health. This article may require Definition and overview[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=1)] Hygiene is a practice [[3]](#cite_note-3) related to [lifestyle](/wiki/Lifestyle_(sociology)), [cleanliness](/wiki/Cleanliness), [health](/wiki/Health), and [medicine](/wiki/Medicine). In medicine and everyday life, hygiene practices are preventive measures that reduce the incidence and spread of germs leading to [disease](/wiki/Disease).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Hygiene practices vary from one [culture](/wiki/Culture) to another. [[4]](#cite_note-4) In the manufacturing of food, [[5]](#cite_note-5) pharmaceuticals, [[6]](#cite_note-6) cosmetics, [[7]](#cite_note-7) and other products, good hygiene is a critical component of [quality assurance](/wiki/Quality_assurance). The terms cleanliness and hygiene are often used interchangeably, which can cause confusion. In general, hygiene refers to practices that prevent spread of disease-causing organisms. Cleaning processes (e.g., [handwashing](/wiki/Hand_washing) [[1]](#cite_note-:1-1)) remove infectious microbes as well as dirt and soil, and are thus often the means to achieve hygiene. Other uses of the term are as follows: and everyday hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=2)] Home hygiene overview[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=3)] Home hygiene pertains to the hygiene practices that prevent or minimize the spread of disease at home and other everyday settings such as social settings, public transport, the workplace, public places, and more.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Hygiene in a variety of settings plays an important role in preventing the spread of infectious diseases. [[8]](#cite_note-globalburden-8) It includes procedures like hand hygiene, respiratory hygiene, food and water hygiene, general home hygiene (hygiene of environmental sites and surfaces), care of domestic animals, and home health care (the care of those who are at greater risk of infection).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] At present, these components of hygiene tend to be regarded as separate issues, although based on the same underlying microbiological principles. Preventing the spread of diseases means breaking the chain of infection transmission so that infection cannot spread. "Targeted hygiene" is based on identifying the routes of pathogen spread in the home and introducing hygiene practices at critical times to break the chain of infection. [[9]](#cite_note-:2-9) It uses a [risk-based approach](/wiki/Probabilistic_risk_analysis) based on Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point ( [HACCP](/wiki/HACCP)).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The main sources of infection in the home are people (who are carriers or are infected), foods (particularly raw foods), water, pets, and domestic animals. [[10]](#cite_note-bloomfield2012-10) Sites that accumulate stagnant water - such as sinks, [toilets](/wiki/Toilet), waste pipes, cleaning tools, and face cloths - readily support microbial growth and can become secondary reservoirs of infection, though species are mostly those that threaten "at risk" groups. [Pathogens](/wiki/Pathogens) (such as potentially infectious bacteria and viruses - colloquially called "germs") are constantly shed via mucous membranes, feces, vomit, skin scales, and other means. When circumstances combine, people are exposed, either directly or via food or water, and can develop an infection.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The main "highways" for the spread of pathogens in the home are the hands, hand and food contact surfaces, and cleaning cloths and utensils (e.g. [fecal-oral route](/wiki/Fecal%E2%80%93oral_route) of transmission). Pathogens can also be spread via clothing and household linens, such as [towels](/wiki/Towels). Utilities such as toilets and wash basins were invented to deal safely with human waste but still have risks associated with them. Safe disposal of human waste is a fundamental need; poor [sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation) is a primary cause of diarrhea disease in low-income communities. Respiratory viruses and fungal spores spread via the air.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Good home hygiene means engaging in hygiene practices at critical points to break the chain of infection. [[9]](#cite_note-:2-9) [[10]](#cite_note-bloomfield2012-10) Because the "infectious dose" for some pathogens can be very small (10-100 viable units or even less for some viruses), and infection can result from direct transfer of pathogens from surfaces via hands or food to the mouth, nasal mucous, or the eye, "hygienic cleaning" procedures should be adopted to eliminate pathogens washing](/wiki/Hand_washing) (or handwashing), also known as hand hygiene, is the act of cleaning one's [hands](/wiki/Hand) with [soap or handwash](/wiki/Soap) and [water](/wiki/Water) to remove [viruses](/wiki/Virus)/ [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria)/ [microorganisms](/wiki/Microorganism), dirt, grease, or other harmful and unwanted substances stuck to the hands. Drying of the washed hands is part of the process as wet and moist hands are more easily recontaminated. [[11]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_CDC2020Wash2-11) [[12]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_Huang2012-12) If soap and water are unavailable, that is at least 60% ( [v/v](/wiki/V/v)) [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_(chemistry)) in water can be used as long as hands are not visibly excessively dirty or greasy. [[13]](#cite_note-13) [[14]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_Centers_for_Disease_Control-14) Hand hygiene is central to preventing the spread of [infectious diseases](/wiki/Infection) in home and everyday life settings. [[15]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_hand_hygiene-15) [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization)(WHO) recommends washing hands for at least 20 seconds before and after certain activities. [[16]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_:7-16) [[17]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_:8-17)These include the five critical times during the day where washing hands with soap is important to reduce [fecal-oral transmission](/wiki/Fecal%E2%80%93oral_route)of disease: after using cleaning a child's bottom (changing [diapers](/wiki/Diaper)), before feeding a child, before eating and before/after preparing food or handling raw meat, fish, or poultry. [[18]](#cite_note-Hand_washing_:2-18) Respiratory hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=5)] Correct respiratory and [hand hygiene](/wiki/Hand_hygiene) when coughing and sneezing reduces the spread of pathogens particularly during the [cold](/wiki/Cold) and [flu](/wiki/Flu) season: [[8]](#cite_note-globalburden-8) - Carry tissues and use them to catch coughs and sneezes, or sneeze into your elbow. - Dispose of tissues as soon as possible. Hygiene in the kitchen, bathroom and toilet[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=6)] Routine cleaning of hands, food, sites, and surfaces (such as [toilet seats](/wiki/Toilet_seat) and [flush](/wiki/Flush_toilet) handles, door and tap handles, work surfaces, and bath and basin surfaces) in the kitchen, [bathroom](/wiki/Bathroom), and [toilet rooms](/wiki/Toilet_(room)) reduces the spread of pathogens. [[19]](#cite_note-hygiene_procedures-19) The infection risk from [flush toilets](/wiki/Flush_toilet) is not high, provided they are properly maintained, although some splashing and [aerosol](/wiki/Aerosol) formation can occur during flushing, particularly when someone has diarrhea. Pathogens can survive in the scum or scale left behind on baths, [showers](/wiki/Shower), and washbasins after washing and bathing.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Thorough cleaning is important to prevent the spread of fungal infections. Molds can live on wall and floor tiles and on shower curtains. Mold can be responsible for infections, cause allergic reactions, deteriorate/damage surfaces, and cause unpleasant odors. Primary sites of fungal growth are inanimate surfaces, including carpets and soft furnishings. [[20]](#cite_note-Cole2000-20) Airborne fungi are usually associated with damp conditions, poor ventilation, or closed air systems.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Hygienic cleaning can be done through:[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] - Mechanical removal (i.e., cleaning) using a [soap](/wiki/Soap)or [detergent](/wiki/Detergent). To be effective as a hygiene measure, this process must be followed by thorough rinsing under running water to remove pathogens from the surface. - Using a process or product that inactivates the pathogens in situ. Pathogen kill is achieved using a "micro-biocidal" product, i.e., a [disinfectant](/wiki/Disinfectant)or [antibacterial](/wiki/Antibacterial)product; [waterless hand sanitizer](/wiki/Hand_sanitizer); or by application of heat. - In some cases combined pathogen removal with kill is used, e.g., laundering of clothing and household linens such as towels and bed linen. Laundry hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=7)] [Laundry](/wiki/Laundry) hygiene involves practices that prevent disease and its spread via soiled clothing and household linens such as towels. [[21]](#cite_note-bloomfield2011-21) Items most likely to be contaminated with pathogens are those that come into direct contact with the body, e.g., underwear, personal towels, facecloths, nappies. Cloths or other fabric items used during food preparation, or for cleaning the toilet or cleaning up material such as feces or vomit are a particular risk. [[10]](#cite_note-bloomfield2012-10) Microbiological and epidemiological data indicates that clothing and household linens are a risk factor for infection transmission in home and everyday life settings as well as institutional settings. The lack of quantitative data linking contaminated clothing to infection in the domestic setting makes it difficult to assess the extent of this risk. [[21]](#cite_note-bloomfield2011-21) [[10]](#cite_note-bloomfield2012-10) [[22]](#cite_note-larson2004-22) This also indicates that risks from clothing and household linens are somewhat less than those associated with hands, hand contact and food contact surfaces, and cleaning cloths, but even so these risks need to be managed through effective laundering practices. In the home, this should be carried out as part of a multibarrier approach to hygiene which includes hand, food, respiratory, and other hygiene practices. [[21]](#cite_note-bloomfield2011-21) [[10]](#cite_note-bloomfield2012-10) [[22]](#cite_note-larson2004-22) Infectious disease risks from contaminated clothing can increase significantly under certain conditions, e.g., in healthcare situations in hospitals, care homes, and the domestic setting where someone has diarrhoea, vomiting, or a skin or wound infection. The risk increases in circumstances where someone has reduced immunity to infection. Hygiene measures, including laundry hygiene, are an important part of reducing spread of antibiotic-resistant strains of infectious organisms. [[23]](#cite_note-reccom-23) [[24]](#cite_note-bloomfield2013-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) In the community, otherwise-healthy people can become persistent skin carriers of [MRSA](/wiki/Methicillin-resistant_Staphylococcus_aureus), or faecal carriers of enterobacteria strains which can carry multi-antibiotic resistance factors (e.g. [NDM-1](/wiki/New_Delhi_metallo-beta-lactamase_1) or [ESBL](/wiki/Beta-lactamase#Extended_spectrum_beta-lactamase_(ESBL))-producing strains). The risks are not apparent until, for example, they are admitted to hospital, when they can become "self infected" with their own resistant organisms following a surgical procedure. As persistent nasal, skin, or bowel carriage in the healthy population spreads "silently" across the world, the risks from resistant strains in both hospitals and the community increases. [[24]](#cite_note-bloomfield2013-24) In particular the data indicates that clothing and household linens are a risk factor for spread of [S. aureus](/wiki/Staphylococcus_aureus) (including MRSA and [PVL](/wiki/Panton%E2%80%93Valentine_leukocidin)-producing MRSA strains), and that effectiveness of laundry processes may be an important factor in defining the rate of community spread of these strains. [[21]](#cite_note-bloomfield2011-21) [[26]](#cite_note-bllomfield2006-26) Experience in the United States suggests that these strains are transmissible within families and in community settings such as prisons, schools, and sport teams. Skin-to-skin contact (including unabraded skin) and indirect contact with contaminated objects such as towels, sheets, and sports equipment seem to represent the mode of transmission. [[21]](#cite_note-bloomfield2011-21) During laundering, temperature and [detergent](/wiki/Laundry_detergent) work to reduce microbial contamination levels on fabrics. Soil and microbes from fabrics are severed and suspended in the wash water. These are then "washed away" during the rinse and spin cycles. In addition to physical removal, micro-organisms can be killed by thermal inactivation which increases as the temperature is increased. Chemical inactivation of microbes by the surfactants and activated oxygen-based bleach used in detergents contributes to the hygiene effectiveness of laundering. Adding hypochlorite bleach in the washing process achieves inactivation of microbes. A number of other factors can contribute including drying and ironing. Drying laundry on a line in direct sunlight is known to reduce pathogens. [[27]](#cite_note-27) In 2013 the International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene reviewed 30 studies of the hygiene effectiveness of laundering at temperatures ranging from room temperature to 70 °C (158 °F), under varying conditions. [[28]](#cite_note-28) A key finding was the lack of standardization and control within studies, and the variability in test conditions between studies such as wash cycle time, number of rinses, and other factors. The consequent variability in the data (i.e., the reduction in contamination on fabrics) in turn makes it extremely difficult to propose guidelines for laundering with any confidence. As a result, there is significant variability in the recommendations for hygienic laundering given by different agencies. [[29]](#cite_note-29) Medical hygiene at home[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=8)] Medical hygiene pertains to hygiene practices that prevent or minimize disease and the spreading of disease in relation to administering medical care to those who are infected or who are more at risk of infection in the home. Members of "at-risk" groups are cared for at home by a carer who may be a household member and who requires a good knowledge of hygiene. People with reduced immunity to infection, who are looked after at home, make up an increasing proportion of the population (as of 2009 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit), up to 20%). [[8]](#cite_note-globalburden-8) The largest proportion are the elderly who have co-morbidities that reduce their immunity to infection. It also includes the very young, patients discharged from hospital, taking immuno-suppressive drugs, or using invasive systems, etc. For patients discharged from hospital, or being treated at home, special "medical hygiene" procedures may need to be performed for them, such as catheter or dressing replacement, which puts them at higher risk of infection. [Antiseptics](/wiki/Antiseptic) may be applied to cuts, wounds, and abrasions of the skin to prevent the entry of harmful bacteria that can cause sepsis. Day-to-day hygiene practices, other than special medical hygiene procedures, [[30]](#cite_note-30) are no different for those at increased risk of infection than for other family members. The difference is that, if hygiene practices are not correctly carried out, the risk of infection is much greater. Disinfectants and antibacterials in home hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=9)] This section needs additional citations for [Chemical disinfectants](/wiki/Disinfectant) [[31]](#cite_note-31) are products that kill [pathogens](/wiki/Pathogens). If the product is a disinfectant, the label on the product should say "disinfectant" or "kills" pathogens. Some commercial products, e.g. bleaches, even though they are technically disinfectants, say that they "kill pathogens" but are not actually labelled as "disinfectants". Not all disinfectants kill all types of pathogens. All disinfectants kill bacteria (called bactericidal). Some also kill fungi (fungicidal), bacterial spores (sporicidal), or viruses (virucidal). An [antibacterial](/wiki/Antibacterial_soap) product acts against bacteria in some unspecified way. Some products labelled "antibacterial" kill bacteria while others may contain a concentration of active ingredient that only prevents them from multiplying. It is, therefore, important to check whether the product label states that it "kills bacteria". An antibacterial is not necessarily anti-fungal or anti-viral unless this is stated on the label. The term [sanitizer](/wiki/Disinfection) has been used to define substances that both clean and disinfect. More recently this term has been applied to alcohol-based products that disinfect the hands ( [alcohol hand sanitizers](/wiki/Hand_sanitizer)). Alcohol hand sanitizers however are not considered to be effective on soiled hands. [[32]](#cite_note-32) The term [biocide](/wiki/Biocide) is a broad term for a substance that kills, inactivates or otherwise controls living organisms. It includes [antiseptics](/wiki/Antiseptics) and disinfectants, which combat micro-organisms, and [pesticides](/wiki/Pesticides). Personal hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=10)] Regular activities[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=11)] Personal hygiene involves those practices performed by a person to care for their bodily health and well-being through cleanliness. Motivations for personal hygiene practice include reduction of personal illness, healing from illness, optimal health and sense of wellbeing, social acceptance, and prevention of spread of illness to others. What is considered proper personal hygiene can be culture-specific and may change over time. Practices that are generally considered proper hygiene include showering or bathing regularly, [washing hands](/wiki/Hand_washing) regularly and especially before handling food, washing scalp hair, keeping hair short or removing hair, wearing clean clothing, brushing teeth, and trimming fingernails and toenails. Some practices are gender-specific, such as by a woman during her [menstruation](/wiki/Menstruation). [Toiletry bags](/wiki/Toiletry_bag) hold body hygiene and toiletry supplies. [Anal hygiene](/wiki/Anal_hygiene) is the practice that a person performs on their anal area after [defecation](/wiki/Defecation). The [anus](/wiki/Anus) and [buttocks](/wiki/Buttocks) may be either washed with liquids or wiped with [toilet paper](/wiki/Toilet_paper), or by adding [gel wipe](/wiki/Gel_wipe) to toilet tissue as an alternative to [wet wipes](/wiki/Wet_wipes) or other solid materials in order to remove remnants of [feces](/wiki/Human_feces). People tend to develop a routine for attending to their personal hygiene needs. Other personal hygienic practices include covering one's mouth when coughing, disposal of soiled tissues appropriately, making sure toilets are clean, and making sure food handling areas are clean, besides other practices. Some cultures do not kiss or shake hands in order to reduce transmission of bacteria by contact. [Personal grooming](/wiki/Personal_grooming) extends personal hygiene as it pertains to the maintenance of a good personal and public appearance, which need not necessarily be hygienic. It may involve, for example, using deodorants or perfume, shaving, or combing. Hygiene of internal ear canals[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=12)] Excessive cleaning of the [ear canals](/wiki/Ear_canals) can result in infection or irritation. The ear canals require less care than other parts of the body because they are sensitive and mostly self-cleaning. There is a slow and orderly migration of the skin lining the ear canal from the eardrum to the outer opening of the ear. Old earwax is constantly being transported from the deeper areas of the ear canal out to the opening where it usually dries, flakes, and falls out. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Attempts to clean the ear canals through the removal of [earwax](/wiki/Earwax) can push debris and foreign material into the ear that the natural movement of ear wax out of the ear would have removed. Oral hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=13)] It is recommended[ [by whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] that all healthy adults brush twice a day, [[34]](#cite_note-34) softly, [[35]](#cite_note-35) with the correct technique, replacing their toothbrush every few months (~3) or after a bout of illness. [[36]](#cite_note-36) There are a number of common oral hygiene misconceptions. The [National Health Service (NHS) of England](/wiki/National_Health_Service_(England)) recommends not rinsing the mouth with water after brushing - only to spit out excess [toothpaste](/wiki/Toothpaste). They claim that this helps [fluoride](/wiki/Fluoride) from toothpaste bond to teeth for its preventative effects against tooth decay. [[37]](#cite_note-37) It is also not recommended[ [by whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] to brush immediately after drinking acidic substances, including sparkling water. [[38]](#cite_note-38) It is also recommended[ [by whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] to floss once a day, [[39]](#cite_note-39) with a different piece of floss at each flossing session. The effectiveness of [amorphous calcium phosphate](/wiki/Amorphous_calcium_phosphate) products, such as Tooth Mousse, is in debate. [[40]](#cite_note-40) Visits to a dentist for a checkup every year at least are recommended. [[41]](#cite_note-41) Sleep hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=14)] Sleep hygiene is the recommended behavioral and environmental practices that promote better quality sleep. [[42]](#cite_note-SH2014-42) These recommendations were developed in the late 1970s as a method to help people with mild to moderate [insomnia](/wiki/Insomnia), but, as of 2014 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit), the evidence for effectiveness of individual recommendations is "limited and inconclusive". [[42]](#cite_note-SH2014-42) Clinicians assess the sleep hygiene of people who present with insomnia and other conditions, such as depression, and offer recommendations based on the assessment. Sleep hygiene recommendations include establishing a regular sleep schedule, using naps with care, not exercising physically or mentally too close to bedtime, limiting worry, limiting exposure to light in the hours before sleep, getting out of bed if sleep does not come, not using the bed for anything but sleep, avoiding [alcohol](/wiki/Alcohol_(drug)) as well as [nicotine](/wiki/Nicotine), [caffeine](/wiki/Caffeine), and other [stimulants](/wiki/Stimulant) in the hours before bedtime, and having a peaceful, comfortable, and dark sleep environment. Personal care services hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=15)] Personal care services hygiene pertains to the care and use of instruments used in the administration of personal care services to people: Personal care hygiene practices include: - sterilization of instruments used by service providers including [hairdressers](/wiki/Hairdresser), [aestheticians](/wiki/Esthetician), and other service providers - sterilization by [autoclave](/wiki/Autoclave)of instruments used in [body piercing](/wiki/Body_piercing)and [tattooing](/wiki/Tattoo) - cleaning hands Challenges[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=16)] Excessive body hygiene is a possible sign of [obsessive-compulsive disorder](/wiki/Obsessive%E2%80%93compulsive_disorder). Neglecting bodily hygiene, or the cleanliness of one's environment, may be a sign of [major depression](/wiki/Major_depression) and other psychological disorders. Hygiene hypothesis and allergies[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=17)] Although media coverage of the [hygiene hypothesis](/wiki/Hygiene_hypothesis) has declined, popular folklore continues to sometimes assert that dirt is healthy and hygiene unnatural. This has caused health professionals to be concerned that hygiene behaviors which are the foundation of public health are being undermined. In response to the need for effective hygiene in home and everyday life settings, the International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene developed a "risk-based" or targeted approach to home hygiene that seeks to ensure that hygiene measures are focused on the places and times most critical for infection transmission. [[9]](#cite_note-:2-9) While targeted hygiene was originally developed as an effective approach to hygiene practice, it also seeks, as far as possible, to sustain "normal" levels of exposure to the microbial flora of our environment to the extent that is important to build a balanced immune system. Although there is substantial evidence that some microbial exposures in early childhood can in some way protect against allergies, there is no evidence[ [no evidence](/wiki/Argument_from_ignorance)] that humans need exposure to harmful microbes (infection) or that it is necessary to develop a clinical infection. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Nor is there evidence[ [no evidence](/wiki/Argument_from_ignorance)] that hygiene measures such as hand washing, food hygiene, etc., are linked to increased susceptibility to [atopic disease](/wiki/Atopy). If this[ [ambiguous](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)] is the case, there is no conflict between the goals of preventing infection and minimizing allergies. A consensus is now developing among experts[ [weasel words](/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words)] that the answer lies in more fundamental changes in lifestyles that have led to decreased exposure to certain microbial or other species, such as helminths, that are important for development of immuno-regulatory mechanisms. [[44]](#cite_note-Rook2010-44) There is still much uncertainty as to which lifestyle factors are involved. Medical hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=18)] Medical hygiene pertains to hygiene practices related to the administration of [medicine](/wiki/Medicine) and medical care that prevents or minimizes the spread of disease. Medical hygiene practices include: [isolation](/wiki/Isolation_(health_care))of infectious persons or materials to prevent spread of infection [sterilization](/wiki/Sterilization_(microbiology))of instruments used in [surgical procedures](/wiki/Surgery) waste](/wiki/Hazardous_waste) - disinfection reusables (i.e., linen, pads, uniforms) - scrubbing up, [handwashing](/wiki/Hand_washing), especially in an operating room, but in more general health-care settings as well, where diseases can be transmitted - ethanol-based sanitizers Most of these practices were developed in the 19th century and were well-established by the mid-20th century. Some procedures (such as disposal of [medical waste](/wiki/Medical_waste)) were refined in response to late-20th notably [AIDS](/wiki/AIDS) and [Ebola](/wiki/Ebola). Food hygiene[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=19)] Culinary hygiene (or food hygiene) pertains to practices of food management and cooking that prevent [food contamination](/wiki/Food_contaminants), prevent [food poisoning](/wiki/Food_poisoning), and minimize the [transmission of disease](/wiki/Disease_transmission) to other foods, humans, or animals. Culinary hygiene practices specify safe ways to handle, store, prepare, serve, and eat food. [Food safety](/wiki/Food_safety)(or food hygiene) is used as a scientific method/discipline describing handling, [preparation](/wiki/Food_processing), and [storage of food](/wiki/Food_storage)in ways that prevent [foodborne illness](/wiki/Foodborne_illness). The occurrence of two or more cases of a similar illness resulting from the ingestion of a common food is known as a food-borne disease outbreak. [[45]](#cite_note-45)This includes a number of routines that should be followed to avoid potential [health hazards](/wiki/Health). In this way, food safety often overlaps with [food defense](/wiki/Food_defense)to prevent harm to consumers. The tracks within this line of thought are safety between industry and the market and then between the market and the consumer. In considering industry-to-market practices, food safety [[46]](#cite_note-46)considerations include the origins of food including the practices relating to [food labeling](/wiki/Food_labelling_regulations), food hygiene, [food additives](/wiki/Food_additives)and [pesticide residues](/wiki/Pesticide_residue), as well as policies on [biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology)and food and guidelines for the management of governmental [import](/wiki/Import)and [export](/wiki/Export)inspection and [certification](/wiki/Certification)systems for foods. In considering market-to-consumer practices, the usual thought is that food ought to be safe in the market and the concern is safe delivery and preparation of the food for the consumer. Food safety, [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition)and [food security](/wiki/Food_security)are closely related. Unhealthy food creates a cycle of disease and [malnutrition](/wiki/Malnutrition)that affects infants and adults as well. [[47]](#cite_note-47) Hygiene aspects in low- and middle-income countries[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Hygiene&action=edit§ion=20)] In [developing countries](/wiki/Developing_country) (or low- and middle-income countries), universal access to water and [sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation), coupled with hygiene promotion, is essential in reducing infectious diseases. This approach has been integrated into the [Sustainable Development Goal Number 6](/wiki/Sustainable_Development_Goal_6) whose second target states: "By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end [open defecation](/wiki/Open_defecation), paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations". [[48]](#cite_note-SDG6-48) Due to their close linkages, water, sanitation, hygiene are together abbreviated and funded under the term [WASH](/wiki/WASH) in [development cooperation](/wiki/Development_aid). About two million people die every year due to diarrheal diseases; most of them are children less than five years of age.
